Sure! Here are some suggestions for VR games and experiences that are less likely to cause negative effects:

1. Puzzle games: Puzzle games in VR can be engaging and immersive without causing motion sickness or cognitive overload. Some popular titles include "Keep Talking and Nobody Explodes," "Statik," and "I Expect You to Die."

2. Relaxation experiences: VR experiences that focus on relaxation and mindfulness, such as meditation or guided breathing exercises, can be an excellent way to de-stress without the risk of addiction or social isolation. Examples include "Guided Meditation VR" or "Nature Treks VR."

3. Exploration games: Games that focus on exploration, rather than fast-paced action, can be a good option for those who are easily overwhelmed by VR environments. Examples include "Minecraft VR" and "Job Simulator."

4. Educational experiences: VR can be an excellent tool for education and learning, with many museums, art galleries, and national parks offering VR experiences. Examples include "Google Earth VR" and "The VR Museum of Fine Art."

5. Creative tools: VR can also be an excellent tool for creativity, with programs like "Tilt Brush" allowing you to paint and draw in 3D space.

Remember to take breaks and listen to your body, and have fun exploring the exciting world of VR!
